title: 111_hr4881
content: The Toxic Drywall Homeowner Relief Act of 2010 allows for deductions for costs to remediate drywall containing elevated levels of sulphur or strontium in the taxpayer's residence and for temporary living expenses incurred due to the presence of such drywall. The Toxic Drywall Homeowner Relief Act of 2010 permits deductions for remediating drywall with high levels of sulphur or strontium in the taxpayer's home and for temporary living expenses due to the presence of such drywall. The Toxic Drywall Homeowner Relief Act of 2010 allows deductions for qualified drywall removal and remediation costs, as well as qualified alternative living costs for eligible individuals. The deduction for drywall removal and remediation costs is limited to $20,000 per year, with certain restrictions on prior deductions. The Toxic Drywall Homeowner Relief Act of 2010 allows deductions for qualified alternative living costs for eligible individuals. The maximum deduction is $12,000 per year, with a limit of $1,000 per month. Eligible individuals must have had drywall installed in their residence between 2004 and 2009, with a reasonable belief that it was manufactured in China. The term 'qualified drywall removal and remediation costs' refers to expenses incurred to remove and replace drywall with elevated levels of sulphur or strontium, replace corroded electrical components and appliances, conduct recommended remediation activities by the Consumer Product Safety Commission, and perform building inspections related to such drywall. The term 'qualified alternative living costs' refers to reasonable lodging expenses incurred by the taxpayer while determining if their principal residence has drywall with elevated levels of sulphur or strontium, and during the removal and replacement of such drywall. Rules similar to section 25D(e) apply for this purpose. The section applies to taxable years after December 31, 2008, and before January 1, 2012. A deduction is allowed for costs related to removing and replacing certain drywall and temporary alternative living expenses. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendment allows for a deduction for costs related to remediating drywall with elevated levels of sulphur or strontium in the taxpayer's principal residence, as well as temporary alternative living expenses. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. The amendment allows a deduction for moving costs associated with vacating a taxpayer's principal residence due to drywall containing elevated levels of sulphur or strontium. The tax credit allows eligible individuals to claim qualified moving costs up to $1,000 for moving from their principal residence to temporary lodging while determining if the residence has drywall with high levels of sulphur or strontium. The tax credit applies to taxable years from 2009 to 2011 and allows for the removal and replacement of drywall with elevated sulphur or strontium levels. The amendment allows for moving costs related to vacating a primary residence due to drywall containing high levels of sulphur or strontium. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008.
